newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.

text.p: -- Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai ended mostly up on Wednesday, with turnover falling to 11.61 million lots from 12.49 million.
The annual rate for the three-day contract rose to 24.50 percent from 21.75 percent on Tuesday and the most active seven-day contract to 14.00 percent from 13.50 percent.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.

Traders said rises of the early-maturing contracts in the past few trading days were mainly due to continued issues of domestic A shares in Shanghai this week. "The stock market is active, attracting liquidity from the repo market," one said.
Traders believe there will be a technical correction after sharp gains in the past few days.

Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly down on Wednesday, with liquidity flowing to the more active stock market, traders said. The most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 closed down at 121.87 yuan from 122.20.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market fell to 2.58 million lots from 3.38 million.
"The T-bill spot market is unlikely to rally in the short term with the stock market absorbing a large amount of money," one trader said. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
